This unit will provide you with an in-depth clinical and translational research knowledge base to generate cutting-edge research questions, and to develop the ability to undertake inquiry-based research.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Translational research and medicine in blood diseases
HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: In this unit, you will develop and demonstrate in-depth knowledge of haematological diseases, a diverse range of conditions affecting the constituents of blood and blood-forming organs. Discipline-specific topics will include diseases of the blood and its components including haemophilia, anaemia, thrombosis, and blood cancers such as leukemia, myeloma and lymphoma. Developing a fundamental understanding of the molecular and cellular changes in specific haematological diseases will provide a contextual basis to identify patient outcomes, justify the use of appropriate technologies to answer patient-specific haematological problems and evaluate pathways to translate haematological research findings into clinical practice. This unit will consist of online specialist lectures delivered by researchers and clinicians actively working in the haematology discipline, and eLearning resources. You will review and evaluate clinical and scientific literature in haematological diseases with a focus on clinical and translational medicine perspectives, and present this information in written form, and via oral presentations and posters suitable for a conference presentation. This unit will provide you with an in-depth clinical and translational research knowledge base to generate cutting-edge research questions, and to develop the ability to undertake inquiry-based research.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: Project 1 explores the implications of intensification for the creation of compact cities. Through projects that engage real spatial settings and the complexities of contemporary environments, the unit helps you develop research foundations, conceptual thinking, analytical approaches and communication skills through planning mechanisms.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: Project 2 explores the creation of ecologically sensitive cities. Through projects that coordinate the built and natural systems that shape our cities, you will develop research foundations, technical capacity, analytical approaches and modes of articulation through planning systems.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Professional practice 1: urban planning and design communication
HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit focuses on the capabilities and core competencies that contribute to the practice of a quality urban planning professional. This unit exposes you to issues around planners' professional abilities, conduct and values, and develops the capabilities to perform ethically and efficiently in addressing complex urban situations. You will develop communication and collaborative skills necessary to help shape inclusive places.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Planning study 1: history and theory of planning and urban design
HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit focuses on the history of planning in Australia and internationally, and on theories in relation to urban development and planning processes. You will gain research and critical capacities for comprehending and applying theories to the urban realm and an awareness of the associated effects on and of urban planning and design programs.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit develops knowledge and skills around the legal and administrative frameworks that underpin the implementation of planning in Australia, set within national and international contexts. You will critically analyse the roles and powers of governments, markets and communities, and their respective impacts on policy and planning instruments.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Planning project 3: planning metropolitan growth areas
HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: Planning project 3: planning metropolitan growth areas considers the role of metropolitan planning in addressing issues associated with urban sprawl. The unit expands and consolidates advanced concepts, knowledge and skills encompassing a range of complex issues relevant to practising urban planning at the metropolitan level. Through critical research, analysis and synthesis undertaken in real spatial settings, the unit develops concepts, creative approaches, processes and outcomes and the skills to communicate these effectively to diverse communities.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: Planning project 4: The inclusive city focusses on issues pertinent to social and community planning to address the challenge of creating people-centred cities. The unit expands and consolidates advanced concepts, knowledge and skills encompassing a range of complex issues relevant to practising urban planning. Through critical research, analysis and synthesis undertaken in real spatial settings, the unit develops concepts, creative approaches, processes and outcomes and the skills to communicate these effectively to diverse communities.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Professional practice 2: analytic methods for urban planning
HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit teaches different tools and techniques used for research in Urban Planning and Design (e.g. GIS, Remote Sensing, and Statistics) and provides hands-on training of their application in the context of strategic land use planning.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Planning study 3: economics and the city
HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit develops skills and knowledge around the historic and current economic structures of cities. You will undertake research into economic approaches to urban development, city infrastructure and service delivery, as well as critically reflect on the economic drivers of cities in Australia and overseas.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit develops knowledge and experience of community engagement theory and techniques, social impact analysis, and the ability to address fundamental issues for diverse communities including indigenous peoples. You will explore methods for deploying new communication technologies, innovative community consultation and conflict resolution strategies through proactive mediations and negotiations.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Work integrated learning: industry placement experience
HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit provides you with work integrated learning experience through a period of approved placement in an urban planning or design entity in the public, private, or community sector. Placement will normally take place in the final semester of study for a period equivalent to one semester 6 credit point unit. The partner organisation provides field supervision, and the faculty provides academic supervision. You will engage in a range of tasks depending on the placement. These may include preparation of plans and urban designs to address and manage land use and development issues and opportunities; gathering and analysis of community data using relevant technical tools including GIS; review and evaluation of strategic planning processes; teamwork with other planners, or with multidisciplinary and diverse groups; and/or application of project management and risk management principles, techniques and tools.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit enables you to conduct scholarly research on topics related to Urban Planning and Design independently and in an ethical manner. You are required to produce a thesis paper at the end of the semester. The paper can take any of the following forms: (a) an independent scholarly research project guided by a thesis supervisor and unit coordinator; (b) a directed thesis contributing to a larger research effort in the discipline; (c) a professional thesis developed in the context of a student. In all cases, the thesis must be a piece of original, creative work conceived and developed by you.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit introduces a pathway for designing interactive experiences through a series of hands-on exercises and projects. You will explore and utilise a creative process of meaning-making through interactive prototypes, group design workshops, peer-presentations, and individual project work. You will learn the foundation of programming principles and techniques, elements of interactive systems, and the use of third-party software to create novel experiences on the web. You will be encouraged to embrace emerging technologies and processes, and develop problem-solving skills in digital media design.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit introduces you to the different aspects of digital imaging for multimedia. The process of creating and using digital imaging effectively is defined and you will gain an understanding of the theory behind the inclusion of digital images in multimedia production. You will undertake project work which explores a range of technical skills and design concepts for incorporating digital images into multimedia production.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: You will be introduced to how the fundamental elements and principles of two and three-dimensional design are applied to Multimedia. You will gain the necessary design skills and knowledge to produce complex integrations of those selected principles of design, which form a solid basis to support visual communications for screen based media. Set projects encourage experimentation with various techniques and methods of interpretation.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit introduces you to the design process, problem solving in visual communications design; and the practicalities of producing type, image, layout and colour for Multimedia environments. You will gain the necessary skills and knowledge to produce complex integrations of those selected principles of design, which form a solid basis to support the design of visual communications for Multimedia/New Media. You will also gain a visual and aesthetic understanding necessary to critically evaluate and analyse the design of multimedia products.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit aims to provide you with the knowledge to develop effective digital media communications. You will investigate graphical user interface design and usability standards as they relate to the presentation of information in an interactive media context. An understanding of the principles that underpin User Interface Design, IA information architecture design and usability standards will be developed. You will explore approaches to user interface and interaction design, develop advanced technical skills with relevant software and hardware, and formulate new responses to participation and experience ideas that are specifically oriented to digital media and its usability.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit introduces you to the fundamental skills, processes, materials and equipment relevant to the practice of contemporary illustration. It endeavours to expose you to a range of illustration styles and techniques, while promoting a broad use of them in traditional and experimental forums. While studying existing illustration styles, you will be encouraged towards an individual image making process that you can develop in future projects, both within this unit and others. The role of illustration as a vital component to contemporary visual communication will be heavily emphasised.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit introduces the fundamental principles of typography. You will utilise type both as a communicative and expressive tool. Contemporary and historical methods of typographic production, from print to digital media are examined. You are encouraged to critically analyse and question the relationships between type and meaning, type and language. Emphasis is placed upon the acquisition of skills and knowledge.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: In this unit you will study the work of innovative visual designers from Modernism until the present. You will analyse how designers use pictorial images and words to convey meanings; and how they achieve this by employing a form of visual language equivalent to written language. Through studying design solutions created in contexts ranging from mainstream graphic design and advertising through to socio-political messages and imagery made by non-designers, you will develop a referential understanding of the potential of visual language for designers. You will then be required to apply this knowledge to the making of designs employing similar problem-solving strategies.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit will emphasise the principle role illustration plays in the practice of graphic design. While continuing to develop individual illustration skills, you will be expected to realise your images in their intended contexts, such as packaging design, shopping bags, book covers, posters, advertisements, or other traditional graphic design formats. While being exposed to traditional image making processes you will also be encouraged to explore more experimental methods. A mix of hand generated imagery and digital methods will be encouraged.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This elective builds upon VCO1302 Typography 1. The unit comprises a series of theoretical and practical exercises. You are encouraged to build upon your skills and knowledge of typography and begin to critically analyse and question the relationships between type and meaning, type and language. Emphasis is placed upon conceptual development and a willingness to approach typography perceptively and with curiosity. You are encouraged to pursue individual outcomes to projects that indicate a willingness to explore and experiment within an awareness of the history of typography. The skills and knowledge acquired form a solid basis to support the major area of graphic design.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit introduces you to the specific skills, demands, practices and opportunities in advertising. In a series of assigned projects involving press, print, signage and television applications, you explore the parameters, opportunities and constraints of these various contexts. You are expected to develop basic skills in all areas of advertising including, concept creation, visualisation, copy writing and art direction. The ethics of practice and the moral responsibility of advertising are actively discussed and debated.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit will demonstrate how an unfamiliar location, experience or culture can effect and inform the process of image making for art and design. Particular emphasis will be placed on the process of gathering information (visual research) and using image making skills to document your findings. From this, you will create a response to the unfamilar environment through a narrative of images that documents your experience. The process is intended to assist you to mature as artists and designers and to allow you to understand the importance of image as a means of communicating without need of verbal language.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: While this unit is concerned with the acquisition of skills to produce fonts digitally, the emphasis is on focused experimentation and the refinement of those skills. You will become familiar with the potentiality and limitations of specific font software packages and learn how to achieve high quality results. This is a highly specialised area of computer-generated typography and offers you the opportunity to be in the forefront of font development. Questions of legibility and the challenging of traditional methods of conveying messages through typography are addressed, discussed and debated.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This is a core unit in the Visual Practices sequence, and is one of four first year units. This unit provides you with an exploration of a broad range of approaches to production methodologies in contemporary visual art for those wishing to work in the arts industry. Topics are delivered in an intensive series of workshop environments and will include experimentation with a range of materials, techniques and conceptual approaches. You will be encouraged to develop inventive solutions to a series of projects set around a variety of themes and concepts appropriate to each workshop. Teaching methods involve technical demonstrations, critical dialogue, class discussion and evaluation. Safe and sustainable approaches to fabrication techniques and materials are promoted as core values in the unit.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: Research practices advanced is a core unit in the Visual Arts sequence, and is the first of the two second year units. This unit is a practice driven, workshop based unit which develops a variety of methodologies and their contribution to a research practice in visual culture. It is designed to further develop, challenge and expand how you think about making artwork and to synthesise research interests, building on VPR1113. A series of individual and collaborative exercises and projects are presented to extend and further foster creative research skills and consolidate your material skills. The main emphasis of this class is to demonstrate how thinking operates through making. Fabrication processes in the workshop can be in any medium from across two- and/or three-dimensional works, to sound and performance. The aim of these exercises is to further extend your capacity for production, creating a pool of ideas, strategies, forms and processes for you to draw on and develop as you progress through the course. Teaching methodology involves critical dialogue, classroom discussion and peer review. This unit presents a broad range of approaches to contemporary art and its institutions for those wishing to work in the arts industry as artists, curators, arts writers, educators or practitioners. Research practices encourages an experimental approach to conceptual, material and public outcomes. Safe and sustainable approaches to fabrication and materials are core values in the unit.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This is a core unit in the Visual Arts and is second of the two second year units. The unit provides you with a broad range of approaches to cultural production for those wishing to work in the visual arts industry across a diverse range of professional platforms. This unit introduces you to various professional processes and outcomes that contemporary visual artists engage and exhibit in. The workshop-driven classes incorporate theoretical and historical perspectives on these gallery-based modes. This unit introduces various steps required to make art public: studio-based processes; the engagement of critical feedback; administrative processes associated with gallery-based exhibition; installing an artwork; and contextualising the artwork in a considered theoretical and curatorial framework. The workshop program facilitates a support structure for the development and consolidation of experimental approaches to conceptual and material outcomes of burgeoning research interests. You are required to investigate and develop individual and collaborative solutions to a series of creative public outcomes. Teaching methodology involves lectures, fieldtrips, critical dialogue, class discussion and peer review. Safe and sustainable approaches to fabrication techniques and materials are promoted as core values in the unit.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit is the fifth in the Visual Practices sequence. In this unit you will focus on your chosen areas of interest reflected in your choice of workshops. Topics will include curatorship, arts writing and a range of contemporary art approaches. A high degree of independence, combined with advanced conceptual lucidity and prowess in the development of curatorial, collective and individual practices should be evident at this stage. You will develop an individual program in conjunction with the lecturer that reflects your personal direction and evolving practice, either curatorial, theoretical or practical.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit is the last and culminating unit in the Visual Practices sequence. In this unit you will focus on your chosen areas of interest reflected in yourchoice of workshops. Topics will include curatorship, arts writing and a range of contemporary art approaches. A high degree of independence, combined with advanced conceptual lucidity and prowess in the development of curatorial, collective and individual practices should be evident at this stage. You will develop a final individual program in conjunction with the lecturer that reflects your personal direction and evolving practice, that provide a bridge to the broader arts industry.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This is a core unit in the Visual Arts sequence and is first of the two third year units. The unit provides you with an advanced perspective on the various modes of publication available to cultural practitioners engaged in Visual Art. This unit gives you an opportunity to incorporate theoretical frameworks that reflect and expand upon a breadth of fields that include education, business, information technology or the liberal arts into your production of visual culture. This unit asks you to develop self-directed strategies that extend upon traditional gallery based exhibition modes. These modes might include: artists' books, editioned objects; site-based research and exhibiting; digital broadcast; collaborative, social and/or performative processes; curatorial contexts; and creative arts writing. The workshop program encourages an experimental and critical approach to conceptual and material outcomes whilst providing opportunities to cultivate curatorial, critical writing and administrative skills. You are required to initiate individual and collaborative solutions to a series of creative public outcomes. Teaching methodology involves lectures, fieldtrips, critical dialogue, class discussion and peer-review. Safe and sustainable approaches to fabrication techniques and materials are promoted as core values in the unit.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit is the last and culminating unit in the Visual Practices sequence and is second of the two third year units. In this unit emphasis is placed on independent cultural research and its relation to a broader collaborative or group context in the public realm. You will develop a creative, expressive and critical project that utilises advanced conceptualisation and material manipulation, engaging with the artwork as part of a chain of production, reception, distribution and publics. You will develop an individual program in conjunction with the lecturer that reflects your evolving cultural practice and professional direction. The program focuses on clear articulation of concepts and their publication in the written form as a supplement to the your Visual Practice. Detailed analysis and discussion of your work takes place primarily through personal tuition with lecturers, peer-based critique and experimenting with various modes of public presentation. This unit provides a stimulating and supportive environment through the introduction of a supervised studio and bridges this to independent professional practice in the broader arts arena. This unit contextualises individual practice within various public platforms that require different modes of group and/or collaborative modes of engagement. The work produced culminates in an end of year exhibition of a professional standard, preparing you for entry into the professional world as cultural producer in broad array of Visual Arts disciplines, or the pursuit of further studies at a higher level.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

HANDBOOK_SYNOPSIS: This unit is used by the Monash University Accident Research Centre and/or Monash Institute of Graduate Research to enrol students undertaking Higher Degrees by Research. Students will not be able to enrol in this unit via WES.

This unit is used by the Monash Sustainability Institute and/or Monash Institute of Graduate Research to enrol students undertaking Higher Degrees by Research. Students will not be able to enrol in this unit via WES.
